1 / 0 || || || || |} ===National Community=== In 1961 each country of the regional assembly of southern South America elected its own National Spiritual Assembly. The election of the Bolivian national assembly - representative of a community the majority of whom were of the [[Aymara ethnic group|Aymara people]] - were (in alphabetical order by last name): Estanislao Alverez, recording secretary, Athas Costas, Sabino Ortega (first Indian teacher), Andres Jachakovo (first Indian believer in Bolivia), vice-chairman, Yolanda de Lopez, secretary, Daniel Mauricio (founder of first Baha'i school), Massoud Khamsi, chairman, Alberto Saldias, treasurer, and Alberto Rocabado.{{cite magazine| title = Eight members of the first National Spiritual Assembly of the Baha'is of Bolivia|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1961 | number = 364 | page =7| url =}} The election was witnessed by Hand of the Cause [[Rahmatu'lláh Muhájir]].{{cite magazine| title = Hands of Faith Plan Extensive Travels|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1960 | number = 357 | page =4| url =}} In 1961 eight of the members of the Local Spiritual Assembly of La Paz were: Hernan Saravia, Jane Khamsi, Isaac Mamani, Lecile Webster, E. Alverez, Livia Barbaro, Morty Landivar, and Massoud Khamsi.no explanation why just 8 are listed {{cite magazine| title = Eight members of the local Spiritual Assembly of La Paz, Bolivia|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1961 | number = 362 | page =15| url =}} and it performed the first [[Bahá'í marriage]] of Bolivia that year.{{cite magazine| title = International News Briefs|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1961 | number = 369 | page =16| url =}} In October the first national Bahá'í school was held on its new permanent location and the students spent the majority of the time clearing the land, planting crops and preparing it for permanent buildings in the village of Meguilla.{{cite magazine| title = Bolivian Believers Hold Unique Summer School on Their Tract of Virgin Land|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1962 | number = 370 | page =9| url =}} By summer 1962 there were nearly 4,000 Baha'is in 321 localities, with sixty-two local assemblies{{cite magazine| title =International Council Recounts Victories; Progress Among the Indians of Western Hemisphere|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1962 | number = 378 |pages=3–4| url =}} and Hand of the Cause [[Abu'l-Qásim Faizi]] was touring Bolivia{{cite magazine| title =News Items from around the World; Thrilling Developments in the Congo|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1962 | number = 380 |pages=3–4| url =}} where he inaugurated a school for teachers of the religion and attended a national congress.{{cite magazine| title =Hand of Cause A. Q. Faizi Visits Spiritually Resurgent Bolivia|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1963 | number = 383 | page =2| url =}} The school was established and opened with Athos Costa as its director. Courses were given in geography, history, hygiene, health, writing as well as Baha'i subjects like [[Progressive revelation (Bahá'í)|progressive revelation]], [[History of the Bahá'í Faith|its history]], [[Bahá'í teachings|teachings]], and [[Bahá'í administration|administration]] across three 8 hour days with a final test and students left with their own notepad.{{cite magazine| title =National School for Instructors Held in Bolivia|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1963 | number = 383 |pages=2–3|url =}} In April 1963 the members of the national assemblies of the world were the delegates to elect the first [[Universal House of Justice]] to be head of the religion after the death of Shoghi Effendi. The Bolivian members of the national assembly that year were: Estanislao Alvarez, Athos Costas, Mrs. Costas, Massoud Khamsi, Yolanda de Lopes, Sabino Ortega, Alberto Saldias Reyes, Alberto Rocabado, and Andres Jachakollo Ticona. In addition, the national newspaper [[El Diario (La Paz)|El Diario of La Paz]] devoted an entire page to "Centenary of the Baha'i World Faith," with text covering the history, principles, objectives and a list of Bolivians leaving for the first [[Bahá'í World Congress]]. There were illustrations of four [[Bahá'í Houses of Worship]] and the [[Bahá'í World Centre buildings#International Archives|International Archives]] building at the Bahá'í World Centre.{{cite magazine| title =Faith Proclaimed Through Mass Media|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1963 | number = 388 | page =12| url =}} During that congress a similar one was held in Bolivia in Oruro to commemorate the centenary of the events of the [[Ridván]] garden.{{cite magazine| title =International News Briefs|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1963 |number = 388 | page =13| url =}} ==Nine Year Plan and the growth of Bolivian Bahá'ís== During the 1964 national convention to elect the national assembly only twenty-seven of the thirty-eight delegates arrived due to the [[History of Bolivia (1920–1964)#The Bolivian national revolution (1952–64)|political troubles]] and violence in Bolivia. Regardless, Hand of the Cause [[Jalál Kházeh]] presented the ''Nine Year Plan'' from the Universal House of Justice which would then cover 1964 to 1973.{{cite magazine| title = Fourth National Convention Held in Bolivia|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1964 | number = 401 | page =7| url =}} The goals included setting up 1200 centers and 600 assemblies, recognition of the Holy Days is to be obtained, literature was to be translated and published in the [[Chiriguano]], [[Siriano]], [[Yanoiguia]], [[Moxos language|Moxos]], [[Tokano language|Tokano]] and [[Chipaya language|Chipaya]] languages, literature in Quechua was to be enriched and Baha'i education was to be extended to as many youth and children as possible. It was noted that the rate of people joining the religion had substantially slowed that prior year. The religion had been recognized in 1963 by the government{{cite magazine| title =The Faith is Recognized in Bolivia|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1968 |number =425 | page =10| url =}} but the national assembly was legally registered in 1966.{{cite magazine| title = Recently incorporated National Spiritual Assembly…|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1965 |number =444 | page =11| url =}} The now annual national congress of Baha'is in Oruro attracted some seventy-four people for which there was newspaper and radio coverage.{{cite magazine| title = Bolivian Congress Reported in Press and Radio|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1964 | number = 404 |pages=11–12| url =}} [[Hooper Dunbar]], then an Auxiliary Board member and later member of the Universal House of Justice, toured Bolivia in 1964 with local Bahá'ís and Athos Costos, member of the National Spiritual Assembly.{{cite magazine| title = Meager Funds, Physical Hardships and Devoted Teachers Mark Efforts in Bolivia|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1964 |number = 405 | page =5| url =}} The first [[Afro Bolivian]]s joined the religion in 1964.{{cite magazine| title = Pioneers Carmela Jachakolio and Esaollah Rezvani…|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1965 |number = 406 | page =6| url =}} The National Convention of the Baha'is of Bolivia in 1965 was attended by delegates and friends who came from eight of the nine provinces ("Departments") of Bolivia. Hand of the Cause Dr. Muhájir and now Auxiliary Board member Athas Costas attended.{{cite magazine| title = Above: The fifth National Convention…|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1965 |number = 417 | page =9| url =}} In 1966 the national assembly designated five Regional Institutes located in different areas of the country which would have its own director and teacher, both living permanently in the area and dedicating all their time to promulgating the religion.{{cite magazine| title = Bolivia Plans Five Regional Institutes|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1966 |number = 426 |pages=6–7| url =}} The students were envisioned as teachers of teachers - to be taught to help local assemblies in augmenting Baha'i life, to read and write, and establish primary school classes for the children and young people of the nearby villages. The Baha'i National School in Cochabama held a three-month course starting August 1 covering the election and function of the assembly; Baha'i teachings; and the Spanish alphabet.{{cite magazine|title =Training session held at Baha'i National School|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1967 |number = 430 | page =10| url =}} The National Spiritual Assembly of Bolivia met on September 3 with then president of Bolivia, General [[Rene Barrientos Ortuno]] who congratulated the Bahá'ís on their devotion to education.{{cite magazine|title = President of Bolivia Commends Baha'is|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1966 |number = 428 | page =9| url =}} In the winter 1966-67 the Ministry of Indian Affairs in Bolivia issued an official circular letter stating that as the activities of the religion have "no relationship whatsoever with politics", that Baha'is should be accorded freedom of expression, freedom in movement and freedom in worship.{{cite magazine|title = Continuous Achievement of Goals of the Nine Year Plan; Bolivia|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1967 |number = 431 | page =3| url =}} However general unrest in the country prevented many assemblies from forming, though the first Local Spiritual Assembly in [[Beni Department|Beni]], on the Brazilian border, and [[Tarija]], on the Argentine frontier, did form.{{cite magazine|title = Bolivian Convention Reveals New Level of Participation|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1967 |number = 436 | page =4| url =}} In the summer of 1967, Athas Costas, Auxiliary Board member, and Dr. Ouladi, National Spiritual Assembly representative, went on a trip in a Baha'i-owned jeep to meet with local officials in troubled areas in several Departments to specify the non-political nature of the religion and federal endorsement of its freedom to practice the religion.{{cite magazine|title = Bolivia Effects Progress in Official RHognition of the Faith|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1967|number = 437 | page =7| url =}} Copies of the federal registration of the religion as a religion recognized by the government by the Ministry of Justice and Immigration from 1963 were distributed to local assemblies in 1968. Cochabamba was a center of a double event in the summer of 1967. First, a ten-day training course was held in June at the national Bahá'í school for the purpose of training young rural teachers in techniques to be used in the thirty proposed literacy centers to be established in Bolivia. Second, some several thousand visitors came to the first exhibition on the religion in Bolivia across a five-day period. The national assembly planned to take the exhibition on a tour of Bolivia. Radio and newspaper coverage also occurred.{{cite magazine|title = 3000 Visitors View Bolivian Exhibition|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1967|number = 438| page =9| url =}} For twenty-eight days in November 1967 Hand of the Cause [[Rúhíyyih Khanum]] toured Bolivia.{{cite magazine|title = Ruhiyyih Khanum Brings New Vision to Bolivia|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1968|number = 438|pages=6–8| url =}} She spoke to a special group of young instructors while they were engaged in study courses in Cochabamba. She attended the [[Nineteen Day Feast]] in Cochabamba, showing slides of her travels. She gave public talks in La Paz and Cochabamba, and two unscheduled talks to the ''Associacion Feminina Christiana'' as well as some villages where she was welcomed to stay. In August 1968 the first meeting to the newly defined [[Institution of the Counsellors|Continental Board of Counsellors]] for South America met in Cochabamba, Bolivia, with Hand of the Cause Jaláh Khazéh and Hooper Dunbar among the attendees.{{cite magazine|title = First meeting of the Continental Board of Counselors…|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1968|number = 453| page =2| url =}} In 1969 there were about 208 local assemblies with 20 full-time Bolivian instructors and 70 to 100 who gave shorter periods of service to teaching. The plan was for each teacher, accompanied by a pioneer, to visit 20 communities each month and to find others who could be trained in practical steps of administration. A particular problem was that the population in the [[Altiplano]] was largely nomadic, moving to gather and sell the annual harvest. Many of them are away during the elections Bahá'ís hold in April.{{cite magazine|title = Goals Committee Members Visit South America; Bolivia|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1969|number = 463| page =14| url =}} In September 1969 the first study course in the history of Bolivia for campesino Indian women was held under the auspices at the Local Spiritual Assembly of La Paz and the Regional Teaching Committee of Departmento La Paz.{{cite magazine|title = Goals Committee Members Visit South America; Bolivia|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1970|number = 466| page =10| url =}} The Cúellars moved to the United States in 1969 to live near their daughter. For her service to the religion Sra. Cúellar was titled the "Spiritual Mother of Bolivia".{{cite magazine|title = 'Spiritual Mother of Bolivia' dies at 87|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1984|number = 638| page =12| url =| ISSN=0195-9212}} Also that year Andres Jachakovo was appointed as an Auxiliary Board member.{{cite magazine|title = Bolivia; Recently appointed Auxiliary Board members …|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1970|number = 470| page =7| url =}} Twenty four youth converted to the religion together in [[Santa Cruz de la Sierra]], a location that had had little conversion activity, in March 1970.{{cite magazine|title = Bolivia|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1970|number = 471| page =21| url =}} In June Hand of the Cause [[Enoch Olinga]] spent two weeks touring Bolivia. He gave well-attended conferences in the ''Club Aleman'' in La Paz and in the [[Universidad Técnica de Oruro]] as well as visiting among villages in the Departments of La Paz, Cochabamba, Drura, Potosí, and Chuquisaca.{{cite magazine|title = The Visit, In Bolivia, of Hand of the Cause Enoch Olinga|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1970|number = 474|pages=3–4| url =}} In August Hand of the Cause Rúhíyyih Khanum returned to Bolivia representing the Universal House of Justice at a continental conference held in Bolivia.{{cite book | last =prepared under the supervision of the Universal House of Justice | first = | title = Bahá'í Era 136-140 (1979-1983) | publisher =Bahá'í World Centre, via University Press, Oxford, by David Stanford Printer to the University | series =The Bahá'í World; An International Record | volume = XVIII | year = 1986 | pages =111, 115, 226, 229, 242, 446, 823–824, 845 | url =http://bahai-library.com/pdf/bw/bahai_world_volume_18.pdf | isbn =0-85398-234-1 }} Some 600 Bahá'ís attended including six Continental Counselors, a dozen auxiliary board members, and 39 members of national assemblies from 19 countries.{{cite magazine|title = Continental and Oceanic Conferences; Bolivia|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1970|number = 475|pages=1–3| url =}} It was announced that 30,000 people had joined the religion from April 1969 to the time of the conference from across South America.{{cite magazine|title = La Paz, Bolivia |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1970|number = 475|pages=2–4| url =}} Coverage in newspapers, radio, and television accompanied the conference was capped by the surprise reception of the President of Bolivia for some 350 Bahá'ís the day after the conference where he mentioned he had visited Haifa and knew of the Bahá'í Holy Places. By 1971 the aftereffects of the conference showed an increase in conversions to the religion including the first Baha'is in the last Department of the country previously with no Bahá'ís and the conversion of a Christian minister who led hundreds more to the religion – all together some 9000 conversions by May 1971 with the largest concentration in the area of Santa Cruz.{{cite magazine|title = Renewed Mass Conversion in Bolivia Result of La Paz Continental Conference|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1971|number = 482|pages=2–5| url =}} That was raised to 11,000 by July.{{cite magazine|title = Outstanding Achievements, Goals|magazine= Bahá'í News|date=July 1971|number = 484| page =3| url =}} The [[History of Bolivia (1964–1982)#The Banzer regime|revised civil government of 1971]] remained supportive of the Bahá'ís with permission for a youth conference.{{cite magazine|title = Bolivian Conference|magazine= Bahá'í News|date=December 1971|number =489|pages=18–19| url =}} Facing various difficulties, pioneers who had settled in Beni strove to both to serve the sense of justice of the poor and against lawlessness in the distant countryside.{{cite magazine|title = Soldiers of Light Brave Dark Jungles|magazine= Bahá'í News|date=October 1972|number =489|pages=14–15| url =}} ==The engagement of the national community== In 1975–6 [[Rúhíyyih Khanum]] travelled by boat through the tributaries of the [[Amazon River]] of [[Brazil]] unto and into the high mountain ranges of [[Peru]] and [[Bolivia]]. Thirty six tribal groups were visited over a period of six months; the trip was called ''The Green Light Expedition,''{{cite video | people = Amatu'l-Baha Rúhíyyih Khánum | title = The Green Light Expedition | url = http://www.bahaibookstore.com/productdetails.cfm?PC=7014 | medium = film, remastered DVD | publisher = National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Canada | date = 2000 }}{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{Cite news | author = Bahá'í International Community | title = Standing up for the oneness of humanity | newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service | date = 2003-11-28 | location = Cuidad Colon, Costa Rica | url = http://news.bahai.org/story/250 }}{{Cite news | last = Sadan | first = Mark | title = Mark Sadan - photographer, filmmaker, U.S.A | periodical = BAFA Newsletter | publisher = Bahá'í Association for the Arts & Arts Dialogue | year = 2007 | url = http://bahai-library.com/bafa/s/sadan.htm }} which followed her ''The Great African Safari.''{{cite journal | last =Palin | first = Iain S. | title = Book Review | journal = Bahá'í Journal of the Bahá'í Community of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland | volume = 19 | issue = 2 | publisher = National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of the United Kingdom | year = 2002 | url = http://www.bahaijournal.org.uk/BJ200206/review.htm | accessdate = 2008-03-09| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080316163953/http://www.bahaijournal.org.uk/BJ200206/review.htm| archivedate= 16 March 2008 | deadurl= no}} There have also been projects developed from the original expedition - ''In the Footsteps of the Green Light Expedition''{{cite journal | last = Beers | first = Karim | title = EBBF Profile: Neissan Alessandro Besharati: Flowing Together--Sustainability, Interconnectedness and Income-generation in the Amazon | magazine = INSPIRE | issue = 16 | publisher = European Bahá’í Business Forum | year = 2007 | url = http://ebbf.org/ebbforg/neissan_besharati.html | accessdate = 2010-12-07 | journal = | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110726012535/http://ebbf.org/ebbforg/neissan_besharati.html | archive-date = 2011-07-26 | dead-url = yes | df = }} and ''Tear of the Clouds''.{{cite web | last1 = Sadan | first1 = Mark | last2 = Kelly | first2 = Rebecca | title = Tear of the Clouds | publisher = Market Group Ventures Inc. | url =http://www.rizvanart.com/finearts/marksadan/tear.shtml | accessdate = 2008-03-09}} In 1982 some 1,300 Baha'is from 42 countries gathered August in Ecuador, the second of five such gatherings. 13 Continental Counsellors, representatives of 24 of the 29 National Spiritual Assemblies in Latin America and the Caribbean, and members of 21 Indian tribes from Bolivia, Brazil, Canada, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Panama, Peru, United States and Venezuela attended. The Conferences were dedicated to the memory of [[Bahiyyih Khánum]], Bahá'u'lláh's daughter, on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of her death.{{cite magazine| title = International Conferences Quito: Riding the 'high tide' of victory | ISSN=0195-9212|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1982 | number = 619 | page =3| url =}} Adherents of the religion in Bolivia had again suffered opposition in various locations, both political and religious, so plans were set for appeals to be repeated as before, this time to the civil courts circa 1983-4. ==Socio/economic development== After the period of large scale enrollments especially in the 1960s the pace of conversion slowed. However focus on service through [[socio-economic development]] began to work in a context of sustainable growth of the religion. Since its inception the religion has had involvement in socio-economic development beginning by giving greater freedom to women,{{cite web| last = Momen | first = Moojan | title = History of the Baha'i Faith in Iran | work = draft "A Short Encyclopedia of the Baha'i Faith" | publisher = Bahai-library.com |url =http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_iran#9.%20Social%20and%20economic%20development | accessdate = 2009-10-16}} promulgating the promotion of female education as a priority concern,{{cite journal | last = Kingdon | first = Geeta Gandhi | title = Education of women and socio-economic development | journal = Baha'i Studies Review | volume = 7 | issue = 1 | year = 1997 | url =http://bahai-library.com/kingdon_education_women_development}} often in some practical expression such as by creating schools, agricultural coops, and clinics. In Bolivia that priority for education led to extending the previous work on tutorial school programs in 1983 with a coordinated engagement across the indigenous peoples from North and South America, a Baha'i radio project, a Baha'i university and other projects. Following these projects conversion to the religion moderated but was more sustained. ===Regional system of training institutes=== Through the initiative of the national assembly a 'Yachay Wasi' Bahá'í Tutorial Center was established in Chuquisaca, the heart of the indigenous area of Bolivia and central to the area of the Baha'i population. Its main purpose was to train the teachers for one hundred tutorial schools to be established in the country, many of them in the Departments of Chuquisaca and Cochabamba. In 1984 the Wasi school gained a permanent facility which was extended in 1985{{cite magazine| title = Social/economic development; Number of projects growing rapidly; Bolivia|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1986| number = 660 | page =8|url = | ISSN=0195-9212}} when the first [[Ruhi Institute]] programs coordinated youth to assist these tutorial schools in the country.{{cite magazine| title = Social/economic development; Number of projects growing rapidly; The Americas; Colombia| ISSN=0195-9212|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1986| number = 660 | page =10|url = }} This ongoing effort in regional training schools was lauded by then Vice President [[Julio Garrett Ayllón]] when he received a copy of [[The Promise of World Peace]], a statement by the Universal House of Justice to which Ayllón responded that he agreed that "world peace is not only possible but inevitable".{{cite magazine| title = Around the World; Bolivia|ISSN=0195-9212|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1986| number = 663 | page =15|url = }} ===Trail of Light=== {{main|Bahá'í Faith and Native Americans}} The idea for a ''Trail of Light'', aka "Camino del Sol", occurred during preparations for the first Bahá'í Native Council in 1978 in North America. It was eventually defined as a process whereby native Bahá'ís engaged with diverse native peoples about a number of issues including promulgating their religion as well as organizing councils for the people and encouraged discovery of mutual cultural links across the native peoples.{{cite magazine | title = 'Trail of Light' Native American teaching effort follows North American Baha'i Native Council |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1980 |number = 594 |ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=6–7 | url =}}{{cite magazine | title = Alaska - A Baha'i community grows, matures |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1981 | number = 607 |ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=1–6 |url =}} With increasing prominence of the effort a few years later{{cite magazine |title = Native Council - Nearly 400 indigenous believers in North America attend historic gathering at Mother Temple of West |magazine= Bahá'í News|date=September 1980 | number = 594 |ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=2–5 | url =}}[http://bahai-library.com/francis_gibson_biography Amoz Everett Gibson the First Black Member of the Universal House of Justice] by Richard Francis, 1998 a three-day training and deepening program developed plans and teams of Bahá'ís to travel to different regions to promulgate the religion among the Native Americans. These teams of indigenous Bahá'ís from Alaska, Canada and the 48 contiguous United States represented 10 tribes under the name ''Trail of Light''.{{cite magazine | title = Latin America; 'Trail of Light' sets many hearts ablaze |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1982 | number = 620|ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=10–11 | url =}} Teams formed and moved among the indigenous peoples from North America into South America. The Trail of Light team then continued through [[Bolivia]], [[Chile]], [[Peru]] and finally [[Ecuador]]. Members of the team included three Bolivians - Sabino Ortega and Clemente Pimantel as Quechua speaking Indians, and Andres Jachakollo, an Aymara speaker.{{cite magazine | title = Sixteen Bahá'ís from Central and South America…|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1984 | number = 639 |ISSN=0195-9212 | page =5 | url =}} At one of the early meetings Ortega took a moment to teach the members a dance he knew while they were in South Dakota and during the lesson people came from outside the building to say that three eagles were circling the building which was felt as a moving religious sign to the people there.{{cite magazine | title = 'Trail of Light' visits the United States; South Dakota|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1984 | number = 639 |ISSN=0195-9212 | page =10 | url =}} In July 1983 in La Paz the President of Bolivia welcomed the Trail of Light members in Bolivia. Also present were twelve Ministers of Departments from around the country, some of whom were themselves indigenous. The Governor of the Department of La Paz also greeted the Trail members in his office, stating that he identified with many of the Baha'i principles. Other major events of the team in the capital included two twenty-minute cultural programs for the state-owned television network which were later aired nationwide. The project revisited Bolivia and Peru in 1988. The team of travelers visited individual Bahá'ís, Bahá'í schools, made public presentations, and there was newspaper and television news coverage of the visit.{{cite magazine | title = 'Trail of Light' in Bolivia, Peru|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1989 | number = 699 |ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=2–9 | url =}} The travelers included [[Lakota people|Lakotas]] [[Jacqueline Left Hand Bull]], then a Continental Counsellor, and US National Assembly members [[Patricia Locke]] and [[Kevin Locke (musician)|Kevin Locke]], along with Bolivians Eloy Anello, Athos Costas, Julian Ugarte and Sabino Ortega. Some of the activities undertaken were the pow wow "grand entrance" dance, songs and dances honoring the Creator, an Indian sign language and [[jingle dress]] performance, talks honoring the Incan Empire, other dances honoring women and various legends of the peoples and the [[hoop dance]] and the work of the ''Trail of Light'' was trying to promulgate. ===Bahá'í radio=== {{main|Bahá'í radio}} Bahá'í radio developed in the late 1960s in Ecuador{{Cite book | last = Hein | first = Kurt John | title = Radio Bahá'í - Ecuador; A Bahá'í Development Project | publisher = George Ronald | year = 1988 |page=215 inc. bibliography | url = http://www.grbooks.com/show_book.php?book_id=159 | isbn = 0-85398-272-4}} and was a precursor to the developments in Bolivia in the 1980s, all with the regular feedback from experienced institutions operating out of the [[Bahá'í World Centre]] with Dr. [[David Ruhe]], then a member of the [[Universal House of Justice]]. The development included an emphasis in raising the resources and people to support a radio station in the local area of the station. The development of programming in Quechua, Aymara and Spanish languages to be used by the station was developed through a country-wide production and broadcasting program in 1983 as prelude to opening of the station. In January 1983 a presidential decree allocated a medium-wave radio frequency band to the National Spiritual Assembly of Bolivia for Caracollo, near Oruro, to become 'Radio Baha'i of Bolivia'. Construction of the new AM 1 kW. station and its associated teaching institute were scheduled for completion in January 1984 and for inauguration at [[Bahá'í Naw-Rúz|Naw-Ruz]], the Bahá'í new year, the same year [[WLGI]] came online in the US.{{cite magazine | title = Ridvan 141: Time of promise, challenge |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1984 | number = 620|ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=1–2 | url =}}{{cite magazine | title = Radio Baha'i-Bolivia is on the air |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1984 | number = 643| ISSN=0195-9212 | page =12 |url =}} The radio station covered a region in Bolivia and Peru of over 400 assemblies.{{cite magazine | title = Radio Baha'i marks fourth anniversary |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1986 | number = 659|ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=2–3 |url =}} Its call letters are CP-220.{{cite magazine | title = The following - courtesy of the International Bahá'í Audio-Visual Centre…|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1987 | number = 659|ISSN=0195-9212 | page =7 |url =}} The station used [[alternative energy]] systems as well as an [[appropriate technology]] setup which allowed its relative low power output to rival the effectiveness of stations with more raw broadcasting power.{{cite magazine | title = Baha'i Radio; Using appropriate energy sources|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1987 | number = 659|ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=6–9 |url =}} Its call letters are CP220 and it is still on the air.[http://fmscan.org/net.php?r=m&m=s&itu=BOL&pxf=CP220+Radio+Baha'i+de+Bolivia CP220 Radio Baha\'i de Bolivia - AM Frequencies], by Günter Lorenz for fmscan.org ===Nur University=== {{main|Nur University (Bolivia)}} In 1983 Bahá'ís of Bolivia were planning to establishing a university at Santa Cruz with educational extension programs for rural areas. The project gathered effort as institutions were developed to aide indigenous populations. Two institutions - the FUNIDEAQ,{{cite magazine | title = The World; Bolivia |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1985 | number = 653|ISSN=0195-9212 | page =15 |url = }} the Foundation for the Development and Education of Aymara and Quechua Peoples, and FUNDESIB,{{cite magazine | title = Teaching accelerates in Chaco area |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1987 | number = 669|ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=12–13 |url = }} the Foundation for the Integral Development of Bolivia, were established by the National Assembly of Bolivia and hoped that they would serve as an alternative to politically based indigenous or government programs which were seen as promoting hatred or violence by the Bahá'ís, See [[FUNDAEC]], for a similar organization in Colombia, where some guidance was borrowed from. One of their early focuses was the development of ''Nur University''{{cite magazine | title = FUNDESIB aids development work |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1988 | number = 685|ISSN=0195-9212 |pages=10–11 |url = }} which was established as a [[Bahá'í school]] of secondary education in August 1984 and started its first academic year in April 1985.[https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=es&u=http://www.nur.edu/index.php%3Foption%3Dcom_content%26task%3Dview%26id%3D28%26Itemid%3D267&prev=/search%3Fq%3Dbah%25C3%25A1%2527%25C3%25AD%2Bsite:www.nur.edu%26hl%3Den%26biw%3D1183%26bih%3D715%26prmd%3Dimvnslb&sa=X&ei=1Jt0UPasEoWx0QHRt4C4Bg&ved=0CCkQ7gEwAQNur University Educational Philosophy], Official Website, Universidad Nur Nur University received Presidential Decree No. 20441 authorizing its establishment as a private university and began offering undergraduate programs in 1985 and became Bolivia's first graduate college in 1994. Beginning in 2000 the university received awards and grants and in 2001 Nur was evaluated as a "full university". In 2002 it was selected as a "Center for Educational Excellence" for the Andean region: an initiative launched at the [[Summits of the Americas|Summit for the Americas]], supported by the United States Agency for International Development (USAID).[http://www.studentie.ro/studyabroad/universitati-din-bolivia-i77-c336/universidad-nur-id4051 UNIVERSIDAD NUR], »Foreign Universities »South American Universities »Universitati din Bolivia, by Studentie.ro ===Other=== A generation after Bahá'í activity in the [[Gran Chaco Province|Chaco Province]] had ebbed it was re-established via FUNDESIB, who encountered Bahá'ís who remembered activity from before and welcomed the new focus during a period of increasing economy distress. FUNDESIB also held the first Bahá'í oriented development conference in Bolivia in November 1987 which included representatives from most of the above initiatives. Baha'is also joined the Bolivian application of the [[International Year of Peace]] for 1986.{{cite magazine | title = The World; Bolivia |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1985 | number = 669|ISSN=0195-9212 | page =14 |url = }} Bahá'ís who had graduated from early schools of the religion sometimes became teachers in the successive wave of school developments.{{cite magazine | title = The World; Bolivia |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1989 | number = 696|ISSN=0195-9212 | page =15 |url = }} A national conference on women was held March 1989 and in various places conversion rates to the religion had again entered the rate of thousands per year.{{cite magazine | title = The World; Bolivia |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1989 | number = 699|ISSN=0195-9212 | page =17 |url = }} ==Recent situation== In 1991 Bahá'ís continued socio/economic development programs with the establishment of a reforestation project which reached a size and set of results by 1995 that neighboring communities consulted on how to use the project in their own areas.[http://www.onecountry.org/oc73/oc7304as.html Reforesting a mountain desert on Bolivia's altiplano], One Country, Volume 7, Issue 3 October - December 1995 Graduates of Nur University had gained opportunities to serve in a number of circumstances both in the cities and countryside. Perhaps the most prominent of Nur's graduates was the 2001 mayor of Santa Cruz,[http://www.onecountry.org/e134/e13413as_Nur_sidebar.htm Nur University: training a new generation of leaders], One Country, Volume 13, Issue 4 / January–March 2002 while the university continued to grow programs for outreach.[http://www.onecountry.org/e144/e14411as_Nur_grant_story.htm Nur University embarks major new teacher training program in Bolivia], One Country, Volume 14, Issue 4 / January–March 2003[http://www.onecountry.org/e134/e13401as_Nur_Moral_leadership.htm In Bolivia, a distinctive training program in moral leadership shines brightly], One Country, Volume 13, Issue 4 / January–March 2002 Of its students, 51% have been women and 49% men. Approximately 40% of the students received financial assistance from the University through scholarships, discounts based on economic need or work-study positions. The University employs 180 full and part-time faculty and administrative staff and has an annual operating budget of approximately US$3 million, and in 2001 was the second largest private institution of higher learning in Bolivia.[http://www.bic.org/statements/belief-and-tolerance-lights-amidst-darkness Belief and Tolerance: "Lights Amidst the Darkness"], by the Bahá'í International Community as a Statement of the Baha'i International Community to the International Consultative Conference on School Education in relation with Freedom of Religion and Belief, Tolerance and Non-discrimination, 23 November 2001, Madrid, Spain In 2002, Baha'is in an isolated village help to establish a local school system. The religion had been present since the 1980s and youth had refused to participate in ceremonies in the schools using alcohol. The emboldened youth then challenged their elders on the rate of alcoholic consumption in the community and asked that the money could be pooled for a school. The effort was later expanded when the assembly partnered with other civic organizations.[http://www.onecountry.org/e142/e14204as_Puka_Puka_story.htm In Bolivia, an isolated village seeks to establish its own school system in the face of discrimination], One Country, Volume 14, Issue 2 / July–September 2002 A national youth conference for Bolivian Bahá'ís was held for over a hundred people in 2006.[http://www.bahai.org.bo Eventos], by the Asamblea Espiritual Nacional de los Bahá'ís de Bolivia, 2006 Translations of Bahá'í literature into a number of dialects of the indigenous in Bolivia have been done before 2007.[http://www.bahai-site.org/writings/american.html The Short Obligatory Prayer by Baha'u'llah], American Languages, The Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of Escondido, January 17, 2007 The government of Bolivia has taken note of the [[persecution of Bahá'ís]] in Iran in 2008.[http://www.eldiario.net/noticias/2008/2008_10/nt081021/8_10int.php Preocupación de ONU por derechos humanos y la discriminación en Irán], El Diario of La Paz, October 21, 2008. ===Demographics=== The Bahá'í Faith is currently the largest international religious minority in Bolivia. The population is the largest population of Bahá'ís in South America. The country's general population is estimated to be 55%-70% indigenous and 30%-42% [[Mestizo]], with a Bahá'í population estimated at 217,000 in 2005 according to the [[Association of Religion Data Archives]]. ==See also== *[[Bahá'í Faith by country]] *[[History of Bolivia]] *[[Religion in Bolivia]] *[[Bahá'í Faith and Native Americans]] ==References== {{reflist|3}} ==External links== *[http://www.bahai.org.bo Bolivian Bahá'í National Community] **[http://www.bahaiprayers.org/ay/index.htm Bahá’í Prayers in Aymara] **[http://www.bahaiprayers.org/qu/index.htm Bahá’í Prayers in Quechua] {{Latin America and the Caribbean topic|Bahá'í Faith in}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Baha'i Faith in Bolivia}} [[Category:Bahá'í Faith by country|Bolivia]] [[Category:Religion in Bolivia]] [[Category:Bahá'í Faith in South America|Bol]]

{{Italic title}} [[File:Garden1000Buddhas9.JPG|thumb|right|[[Garden of One Thousand Buddhas]] Arlee, [[Montana]]]]
'''''Bhadrakalpikasūtra''''' ([[Sanskrit]]; {{bo|w=bskal pa bzang po’i mdo}}) is a [[Mahayana sutras|Mahayana sutra]] with 24 chapters written in c. 200-250 CE,<ref>The Princeton Dictionary of Buddhism, By Robert E. Buswell Jr., Donald S. Lopez Jr., Princeton University Press, 2013 p. 106</ref> said to have been taught by [[Gautama Buddha]] in [[Vaishali (ancient city)|Vaishali]].<ref>The Fortunate Aeon: How the Thousand Buddhas Became Enlightened (Tibetan Translation Series), 4 volume set (Berkeley: Dharma Publishing, 1986).</ref> It includes the names of the 1002 Buddhas of this "Fortunate Aeon."<ref>“One Thousand Buddhas from Gandhara: the Bhadrakalpikasutra and its place in Gandhari literature,” Stefan Baums, 44th Annual South Asian Conference of the Pacific Northwest, March 4–6, 2010.</ref> The title of this text means the ''Fortunate Aeon Sūtra''.
==The thousand buddhas== [[File:Dunhuang Cave 16.jpg|thumb| Photo showing [[Dunhuang]] Cave 16 and the manuscripts piled up for [[Aurel Stein]] near the entrance to Cave 17, the “library cave” at the [[Mogao Caves]]]] [[File:Temple des 1000 Boudhas 2.JPG|thumb|[[Temple of One Thousand Buddhas]], in [[la Boulaye]], [[Saône-et-Loire]], [[Burgundy]]]]
The list of 1002 (or 1004) names starts with:<ref>The Fortunate Aeon: How the Thousand Buddhas Became Enlightened, p. 1733</ref>
* [[Kakusandha Buddha|Krakucchanda]] * [[Koṇāgamana Buddha|Kanakamuni]] * [[Kassapa Buddha|Kashyapa]] * [[Shakyamuni]] * [[Maitreya]]
... and ends with ...<ref>The Fortunate Aeon: How the Thousand Buddhas Became Enlightened, p. 1733</ref>
* Harivaktra * Chuda and * Rocha
It is included in the first volume of the sutra section of the [[Kangyur]] of [[Tibetan Buddhism]]. It is also available in Chinese, Tibetan, Mongolian, and other languages in variants that differ slightly as to the number of Tathāgatas enumerated. For example, the [[Saka language|Khotanese]] version is the proponent of a 1005-Tathāgata system.<ref>BHADRAKALPIKASŪTRA, Ronald E. Emmerick, Encyclopaedia Iranica, December 15, 1989, Vol. IV, Fasc. 2, pp. 190-191 http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/bhadrakalpikasutra-the-name-of-a-buddhist-mahayanist-text</ref>
[[Dharmarakṣa]], a native of [[Dunhuang]], between third and fourth centuries had translated the ''Bhadrakalpikasutra'' into Classical Chinese. Note that "A cave of the Thousand-Buddhas" is the name of the world-renowned grottoes at [[Dunhuang]]. Vidyakarasimha and Dpal-dbyans translated the text into Tibetan.<ref>Dr. Shailendra K. Verma, "Emergence and Evolution of the Buddha Image (From its inception to 8th century A.D.)" a doctoral thesis. At http://www.exoticindiaart.com/product/TK70/</ref>
The original Sanskrit text is now lost.
== See also == * [[Mahayana sutras]] * [[Names of God]] * ''[[Heart Sutra]]'' * ''[[Samantabhadra Meditation Sutra]]''
== Notes == {{reflist}}

Bhadrakalpikasūtra. http://beta.worldcat.org/archivegrid/collection/data/840923226] * [http://whav.aussereurop.univie.ac.at/ic/1836/?page=2 Tabo skor lam: inner walls On the inner walls of the ambulatory the sequence of the Buddhas of the Bhadrakalpikasūtra continues] [[Tabo Monastery]]

{{More citations needed|date=May 2014}} [[File:Censusdivisions-ethnic.png|thumb|300px|right|A map of the ethnic origins of Canadians, from the 2006 nation census. The largest self-reported ancestry in each census division is highlighted by colour. As a legacy of the block settlements, the three Prairie Provinces have several regions where ancestries other than British are the largest, unlike the norm in surrounding regions. Areas where people self-identified as having German ancestors are the [[wikt:plurality|plurality]] are coloured in yellow on the map, French in dark blue, and Ukrainian in teal. Most block settlements were not large enough to be visible at this scale, however.]] [[File:Land Ticket.jpg|thumb|CPR land sales advertisement]] A '''block settlement''' (or '''bloc settlement''') is a particular type of land distribution which allows [[settlers]] with the same [[ethnicity]] to form small [[colonies]].
This settlement type was used throughout [[western Canada]] between the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Some were planned and others were spontaneously created by the settlers themselves.
The policy of planned blocks was pursued primarily by [[Clifford Sifton]] during his time as [[Minister of the Interior (Canada)|Interior Minister of Canada]]. It was essentially a compromise position. Some politicians wanted all ethnic groups to be scattered evenly though the new lands to ensure they would quickly assimilate to Anglo-Canadian culture, while others did not want to live near "foreign" immigrants (as opposed to British immigrants who were not considered foreign) and demanded that they be segregated. At the time Canada was receiving large amounts of non-British, non-French, immigrants for the first time, especially [[Italians]], [[Germans]], [[Scandinavia]]ns, and [[Ukrainians]]. The newcomers themselves wanted to settle as close as possible to people with a familiar language and similar customs. The government did not want the west to be fragmented into a few large homogeneous ethnic blocks, however. So several smaller colonies were set up where particular ethnic groups could settle, but these were spaced across the country.<ref>{{cite web | title =Atlas of Saskatchewan (Ethnic Bloc Settlements map)| url =http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~cansk/maps/ethnic-bloc.html|date= | accessdate =2014-05-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title =Ethnic Bloc Settlement in the Prairies| url =http://www.fwalive.ualberta.ca/vmctm_media/Ukrainian/UKR_Clips/UKR3_P4.gif|date=1989 | accessdate =2014-05-31}}</ref>
==Examples of ethnic block settlements in western Canada== {{Expand list|date=August 2008}}
==African American== {{further|Black Canadians}} * [[Amber Valley, Alberta]] * [[Breton, Alberta]] * [[Maidstone, Saskatchewan]].. Charlow (Shiloh) Baptist Church located north of Maidstone in the [[rural municipality]] of [[Eldon No. 471, Saskatchewan|Eldon]] was built in 1912.<ref>{{cite web | title =Charlow (Shiloh) Baptist Church and Cemetery| url =http://www.historicplaces.ca/en/rep-reg/place-lieu.aspx?id=4207&pid=0|date= | accessdate =2013-11-19}}</ref> It was founded by 12 African American families from [[Oklahoma]] in 1910.<ref>{{cite web | title =Shiloh Baptist Church Cemetery| url =http://people.ucalgary.ca/~dsucha/shiloh.html|date= | accessdate =2013-11-19}}</ref> * [[Happy Valley, British Columbia]] * [[Saltspring Island]], British Columbia * [[Wildwood, Alberta]]
==British== * [[Lloydminster]], Saskatchewan/Alberta ([[dry town|temperance colony]]) * [[Walhachin, British Columbia]] * [[Kelowna]], British Columbia
==Doukhobor== {{further|Doukhobor|Christian Community of Universal Brotherhood|Freedomites}} [[File:Geographic movements of the Doukhobors, 1898-1913.jpg|thumb|Geographic movements of the Doukhobors, 1898-1913]] [[Image:Veregin Prayer House.jpg|thumb|The Doukhobor prayer house in [[Doukhobors at Veregin|Veregin]] is a [[National Historic Sites of Canada|National Historic Site of Canada]]]] *In Saskatchewan Doukhobors, numbering 7,500, settled in three blocks in the [[Districts of the Northwest Territories|North-West Territories]] (now in Saskatchewan) from 1899 to 1918. They established 61 communal villages on {{convert|773400|acre|km2}}.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.doukhobor.org/Maps.htm| title=Doukhobor Reserves in Saskatchewan, 1899-1918| accessdate=2014-06-14| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204174503/http://www.doukhobor.org/Maps.htm| archivedate=2012-02-04| df=}}</ref> ([http://www.doukhobor.org/Reserves.gif Map]) **North Colony (1899-1918) contained {{convert|69000|acre|km2}} in the [[Pelly, Saskatchewan|Pelly]]-[[Arran, Saskatchewan|Arran]] area settled by 2,400 settlers in 20 communal villages.([http://www.doukhobor.org/North.gif Map]) **South Colony (1899-1918) contained {{convert|215010|acre|km2}} in the [[Canora, Saskatchewan|Canora]], [[Veregin, Saskatchewan|Veregin]] and [[Kamsack, Saskatchewan|Kamsack]] area settled by 3,500 settlers in 30 communal villages. ([http://www.doukhobor.org/South.gif Map]) **Good Spirit Lake Annex (1899-1918) contained {{convert|168930|acre|km2}} in the Good Spirit Lake and [[Buchanan, Saskatchewan|Buchanan]] area settled by 1,000 settlers in 8 communal villages. ([http://www.doukhobor.org/Annex.gif Map]) **Saskatchewan Colony (1899-1918) contained {{convert|324800|acre|km2}} in the [[Langham, Saskatchewan|Langham]], [[Blaine Lake, Saskatchewan|Blaine Lake]] area settled by 1,500 settlers in 15 communal villages. ([http://www.doukhobor.org/Sask.gif Map]) **Sheho and Insinger (1909-1926) contained {{convert|1280|acre|km2}}. ([http://www.doukhobor.org/sheho-insinger.gif Map]) **[[Kylemore, Saskatchewan]] (1918-1938) north of Fishing Lake. ([http://www.doukhobor.org/Kylemore.gif Map]) **Kelvinton, Saskatchewan (1921-1938) was west of Kelvinton. ([http://www.doukhobor.org/kelvington.gif Map]) *British Columbia (1908-1938) ([http://www.doukhobor.org/Kootenays.gif Map]) ** [[Grand Forks, British Columbia|Grand Forks]]-[[Castlegar, British Columbia|Castlegar]]-[[Slocan Valley]] (1909-1938) was an area of {{convert|19000|acre|km2}} settled by 8,000 Doukhobors from Saskatchewan in 74 communal villages. ([http://www.doukhobor.org/Grand%20Forks.gif Map]) ** [[Brilliant, British Columbia]] (1908-1938) on {{convert|2700|acre|km2}} included 6 communal villages. ([http://www.doukhobor.org/Brilliant.gif Map]) ** [[Ootischenia, British Columbia]] (1908-1938) on {{convert|2700|acre|km2}} included 22 communal villages. ([http://www.doukhobor.org/Ootischenia.gif Map]) ** [[Champion Creek, British Columbia]] (1912-1938) on {{convert|920|acre|km2}} included 5 communal villages. ([http://www.doukhobor.org/Blagodatnoe.gif Map]) ** Glade, British Columbia (1911-1938) on {{convert|1092|acre|km2}} included 11 communal villages. ([http://www.doukhobor.org/Glade.gif Map]) ** Shoreacres, British Columbia (1912-1938) on {{convert|500|acre|km2}} included 3 communal villages. ([http://www.doukhobor.org/Shoreacres.gif Map]) ** [[Pass Creek, British Columbia]] (1909-1938) on {{convert|1760|acre|km2}} included 6 communal villages. ([http://www.doukhobor.org/Pass%20Creek.gif Map]) ** [[Winlaw, British Columbia]] (1912-1938) on {{convert|837|acre|km2}} included 4 communal villages. ([http://www.doukhobor.org/Winlaw.gif Map]) *Alberta ** [[Cowley, Alberta|Cowley]]-[[Lundbreck, Alberta]] (1915-1938) on {{convert|13500|acre|km2}} included 13 communal villages.([http://www.doukhobor.org/Cowley-Lundbreck.gif Map]) ** [[Arrowwood, Alberta|Arrowwood]]-[[Shouldice]]-[[Anastasia, Alberta]] (1926-1945) ([http://www.doukhobor.org/Arrowwood.gif Map])
==Dutch== {{further|Dutch Canadian}} * [[Neerlandia, Alberta]]
==English Canadian== ''Meaning settlers from [[Eastern Canada]], primarily Ontario, and mostly of British and Irish origins.'' {{further|English Canadian}} * [[Saskatoon]] ([[dry town|temperance colony]])
==French== ''These include French Canadians from Quebec, French Americans, and Francophones from France, Belgium, and Switzerland'' {{see also|Franco-Manitoban|Fransaskois|Franco-Albertan|Franco-Columbian}}
''Alberta''
* The [[Bonnyville, Alberta|Bonnyville]] and [[St. Paul, Alberta|St. Paul]] area (Bonnyville, Cold Lake, Fort Kent, La Corey, Lafond, Mallaig, Saint Lina, Saint Vincent, Therien) * [[Lac La Biche, Alberta|Lac La Biche]] and [[Plamondon, Alberta]] * [[Sturgeon County]] and [[Lac Ste. Anne County]], Alberta. Specifically the communities of [[St. Albert, Alberta|St. Albert]], [[Morinville]], [[Legal, Alberta|Legal]], [[Rivière Qui Barre, Alberta|Rivière Qui Barre]], [[Villeneuve, Alberta|Villeneuve]], [[Pickardville, Alberta|Pickardville]], and around the shores of [[Lac Ste. Anne (Alberta)|Lac Ste. Anne]] and [[Lac La Nonne]]. * Smokey River bloc settlement (Donnelly, [[Falher, Alberta]], Girouxville, Guy, Jean Côté, Mac Lennan, Marie-Reine, Saint Isidore, Tangent).
''British Columbia''
*[[Maillardville, British Columbia]] *[[Terrace, British Columbia]]
''Manitoba'' * Rat River settlement (Saint Labre, Saint Pierre Jolys, Saint-Malo) *[[Red River Colony|Red River settlement]] (Saint Boniface, Saint Vital, Saint Norbert, Saint Germain, Cartier, La Salle, Saint Adolphe, Glenlea, Sainte Agathe, Tourond, Aubigny, Dufrost, Saint Jean Baptiste, Sainte Elizabeth, Saint Joseph, Letellier) *[[Seine River (Manitoba)|Seine River settlement]] (Dufresne, Giroux, Ile des Chênes, La Broquerie, Lorette, Marchand, Richer, Saint Raymond, Sainte Anne des Chênes, Sainte Genevieve) * Whitehorse plain settlement (Elie, Fannystelle, Saint Eustache, Saint François Xavier, Saint Laurent, Saint Ambroise) ''Saskatchewan'' [[File:La Cathédrale, Gravelbourg, SK.jpg|thumb|[[Our Lady of Assumption Co-Cathedral|Cathedral in Gravelbourg]]]] *Cantal-Bellegarde settlement ([[Alida, Saskatchewan|Alida]], [[Antler, Saskatchewan|Antler]], [[Bellegarde, Saskatchewan|Bellegarde]], [[Cantal, Saskatchewan|Cantal]], [[Redvers, Saskatchewan|Redvers]], [[Storthoaks, Saskatchewan|Storthoaks]], [[Wauchope, Saskatchewan|Wauchope]]) *Delmas bloc settlement (Cochin, Delmas, Edam, Jackfish Lake, Vawn) *Duck Lake settlement (Domremy, Duck Lake, Saint Isidore de Bellevue, Saint Louis) *Gravelbourg bloc settlement<ref>{{cite web| title =Francophone land settlement in southwestern Saskatchewan by Beckey Hamilton | url =http://pcag.uwinnipeg.ca/Prairie-Perspectives/PP-Vol05/Hamilton.pdf| date = |accessdate =2014-03-23}}</ref> ([[Gravelbourg]], [[Lafleche, Saskatchewan|Lafleche]], [[Mazenod, Saskatchewan|Mazenod]], [[Meyronne, Saskatchewan|Meyronne]]). *Leoville-Debden bloc (Bapaume, Big River, Debden, Laventure, Leoville, Spiritwood, Victoire) *Ponteix settlement (Cadillac, Lac Pelletier, Pambrun, Ponteix, Vanguard) *Prud'homme Vonda settlement (Prud'homme, Saint Denis, Vonda) *Willow Bunch bloc settlement (Assiniboia, Fife Lake, Lisieux, Little Woody, Maxstone, Rockglen, Saint Victor, Verwood, Willow Bunch) *Wood mountain bloc (Ferland, Glentworth, Fir mountain, Wood mountain) * [[The French Counts of St Hubert, Saskatchewan|St Hubert, Saskatchewan]]
===Francophone Métis settlements=== Some French settlements were founded by Francophone Métis from the [[Red River settlement]] in [[Manitoba]]. Many began as Métis [[hivernants]] buffalo hunting camps from the 1840s to the 1870s.<ref>{{cite web | title =Atlas of Saskatchewan (French and Francophone Métis Settlements) | url =http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~cansk/maps/french.html| date = | accessdate =2014-04-06}}</ref><ref name="Welsted1996">{{cite book|author=John Welsted|title=The Geography of Manitoba: Its Land and Its People|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IQKLCbdJ0GQC&pg=PA89|date=1 January 1996|publisher=Univ. of Manitoba Press|isbn=978-0-88755-375-2|page=89}}</ref> * [[Lebret, Saskatchewan]] (St-Florent mission) 1866 and Val Qu'Appelle 1860s * [[Touchwood Hills]] 1860s * [[Southbranch Settlement|St-Laurent-Grandin Métis settlements]] 1868-1876 * [[Wood Mountain, Saskatchewan]] 1870s and [[Willow Bunch, Saskatchewan]] * [[Lac Pelletier, Saskatchewan]]/ Vallée Ste-Claire 1870s * [[Cypress Hills, Saskatchewan]] 1870s * la-Prairie-Ronde near [[Dundurn, Saskatchewan]] 1850s * [[Frenchman Butte, Saskatchewan]] 1880s * [[Cochin, Saskatchewan]] 1880s * [[Delmas, Saskatchewan]] 1880s * [[St-Lazare]] 1880s * [[Val Marie, Saskatchewan]]
==German== {{see also|Canadians of German ethnicity}} * German settlement began in the prairie provinces in the 1890s and continued until the 1920s during the homesteading period. Some also came to the region after the end of [[World War II]]. Canadians of German ethnicity remain numerous in the prairie provinces. Most of these settlers were Catholics and Lutherans, with minorities of Mennonites and Baptists. * around [[Regina, Saskatchewan]] * [[Medicine Hat]], [[Alberta]] - [[Dunmore, Alberta]] * [[Bruderheim]], [[Alberta]] - [[Josephburg, Alberta]] * [[Hilda, Alberta]] - [[Schuler, Alberta]] * [[Hussar, Alberta]] * [[Langenburg, Saskatchewan]] and Hohenlohe<ref name="german roots">{{cite web | title =German Saskatchewan Genealogy Roots | url =http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~cansk/Saskatchewan/ethnic/german-saskatchewan.html | accessdate =2014-05-28}}</ref> * [[Pierceland, Saskatchewan]] * [[Paradise Hill, Saskatchewan]] * [[Leader, Saskatchewan]] * [[Burstall, Saskatchewan]] - [[Richmound, Saskatchewan]] * [[Eatonia, Saskatchewan]] * [[Strasbourg, Saskatchewan]] (New Elsass German Colony)<ref name="german roots"/> * [[Macklin, Saskatchewan]] * [[Lemberg, Saskatchewan]] * [[Neudorf, Saskatchewan]] * [[Heinsburg, Alberta]] - [[Lindbergh, Alberta]] * [[St. Walburg, Saskatchewan]] * [[Goodsoil, Saskatchewan]] * [[Loon Lake, Saskatchewan]] *St. Joseph's Colony (Katharinental) (1886-1904)<ref name="Kronau">{{cite web | title =St. Joseph's Colony, Katharinental Colony, Kronau-Rastadt, and Odessa (1886-1904) | url =http://library.ndsu.edu/grhc/history_culture/history/stjoseph.html | accessdate =2014-05-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title =Historical Sketch of St. Peter's Parish and the Founding of the Colonies of Rastadt, Kathrinenthal and Speier | url =http://library.ndsu.edu/grhc/order/general/speier.html | accessdate =2014-05-28}}</ref> **[[Davin, Saskatchewan]] **[[Rastadt, Saskatchewan]] **[[Kronau, Saskatchewan]] **[[Vibank, Saskatchewan]] **[[Odessa, Saskatchewan]] **[[Kendall, Saskatchewan]]
===St. Peter's Colony=== [[Image:Berthold Imhoff remembered 2 (481919999).jpg|thumb|The interior of [[St. Peter's Abbey, Saskatchewan|St. Peter's Cathedral]] in [[Muenster, Saskatchewan]] was decorated by [[Berthold Imhoff]]]] [[St. Peter's Abbey, Saskatchewan|St. Peter's Colony]]<ref name="St. Peter's Colony">{{cite web |title = St. Peter's Colony Map |url = http://www.ourroots.ca/e/page.aspx?id=1072358 |accessdate = 2014-05-28 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140529085939/http://www.ourroots.ca/e/page.aspx?id=1072358 |archivedate = 2014-05-29 |df = }}</ref> founded in 1903 in Saskatchewan was 4,662 square kilometres (1,800 square miles) in size.<ref>{{cite web | title =Encyclopedia of Saskatchewan (GERMAN SETTLEMENTS) | url =http://esask.uregina.ca/entry/german_settlements.html | date = | accessdate =2012-12-28}}</ref> It included 50 [[Township (Canada)|townships]]; townships 35 to 40, ranges 18 to 22, and townships 37 to 41, ranges 23 to 26 of the [[Dominion Land Survey]] west of the 2nd [[Meridian (geography)|Meridian]].<ref name="cchahistory.ca">{{cite journal | title =St. Peter’s Abbey 1903-1921 |author=Jerome Weber O.S.B. | url =http://www.cchahistory.ca/journal/CCHA1949/Weber.pdf | journal = CCHA Report |volume=16 |year=1949 |pages=37–49 | publisher=Canadian Catholic Historical Association | accessdate =2015-01-26}}</ref> 8,000 settlers had arrived in the colony by 1910<ref>{{cite web |title = Colony Beginnings(p.6) |url = http://www.ourroots.ca/e/page.aspx?id=1072358 |accessdate = 2013-01-06 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140529085939/http://www.ourroots.ca/e/page.aspx?id=1072358 |archivedate = 2014-05-29 |df = }}</ref> and by 1930 it was home to 18,000 Roman Catholics. Most were German Catholics.<ref>{{cite web | title =The German Catholics of St. Peter’s Colony: 1903-1930 By Paul Paproski, OSB | url= http://ecommons.usask.ca/bitstream/handle/10388/ETD-2011-08-25/PAPROSKI-THESIS.pdf?sequence=3 | date = | accessdate =2012-12-12}}</ref> Between 1903 and 1925 parishes were established at [[Leofeld, Saskatchewan|Leofeld]], [[Muenster, Saskatchewan|Muenster]], [[Fulda, Saskatchewan|Fulda]], [[Marysburg, Saskatchewan|Marysburg]], [[Annaheim, Saskatchewan|Annaheim]], [[Englefeld, Saskatchewan|Englefeld]], [[Watson, Saskatchewan|Watson]], [[Lake Lenore, Saskatchewan|Lake Lenore]], [[Bruno, Saskatchewan|Bruno]], [[Humboldt, Saskatchewan|Humboldt]], [[Burr, Saskatchewan|Burr]], [[St. Gregor, Saskatchewan|St. Gregor]], [[Pilger, Saskatchewan|Pilger]], [[St. Benedict, Saskatchewan|St. Benedict]], [[Dana, Saskatchewan|Dana]], [[Carmel, Saskatchewan|Carmel]], [[Cudworth, Saskatchewan|Cudworth]], [[Middle Lake, Saskatchewan|Middle Lake]], [[Peterson, Saskatchewan|Peterson]] and [[Naicam, Saskatchewan|Naicam]].
===St. Joseph's Colony (Josephstal)=== [[St. Joseph's Colony, Saskatchewan|St. Joseph's Colony (Josephstal)]] (1905)<ref>{{cite web | title =St. Joseph's Colony - Index Page | url =http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~skstjose/stjosephs/mainsection/miscellanous/lland.html | accessdate =2014-05-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title =St. Joseph's Colony: 1905 - 1930 | url =http://library.ndsu.edu/grhc/order/general/sjc.html | accessdate =2014-05-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title =Towns & Villages Of St. Joseph's | url =http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~skstjose/stjosephs/mainsection/town/townvillage.html | accessdate =2014-05-28}}</ref> Villages in this Saskatchewan colony included [[Adanac, Saskatchewan|Adanac]], [[Biggar, Saskatchewan|Biggar]], [[Broadacres, Saskatchewan|Broadacres]], [[Cactus Lake, Saskatchewan|Cactus Lake]], [[Carmelheim, Saskatchewan|Carmelheim]], [[Cavell, Saskatchewan|Cavell]], [[Cosine, Saskatchewan|Cosine]], [[Denzil, Saskatchewan|Denzil]], [[Donegal, Saskatchewan|Donegal]], [[Evesham, Saskatchewan|Evesham]], [[Grosswerder, Saskatchewan|Grosswerder]], [[Handel, Saskatchewan|Handel]], [[Kelfield, Saskatchewan|Kelfield]], [[Kerrobert, Saskatchewan|Kerrobert]], [[Landis, Saskatchewan|Landis]], [[Leipzig, Saskatchewan|Leipzig]], [[Luseland, Saskatchewan|Luseland]], [[Macklin, Saskatchewan|Macklin]], [[Major, Saskatchewan|Major]], [[Onward, Saskatchewan|Onward]], [[Pascal, Saskatchewan|Pascal]], [[Phippen, Saskatchewan|Phippen]], [[Primate, Saskatchewan|Primate]], [[Revenue, Saskatchewan|Revenue]], [[Reward, Saskatchewan|Reward]], [[Salvador, Saskatchewan|Salvador]], [[Scott, Saskatchewan|Scott]], [[Tramping Lake, Saskatchewan|Tramping Lake]], [[Unity, Saskatchewan|Unity]], [[Wilkie, Saskatchewan|Wilkie]] and [[Wolfe, Saskatchewan|Wolfe]].
==Italian== * [[Silverdale, British Columbia]]
==Hungarian== [[File:kaposvarchurchkjfmartin.jpg|thumb|150px|Kaposvar Church]] {{see also|Hungarian Canadians}} * [[Esterhazy, Saskatchewan]] (Kaposvar Colony 1886) * [[Kipling, Saskatchewan]] * [[Prince Rupert, British Columbia]] (from 1956 on)
==Hutterite== [[File:Hutterer-Oak Bluff.jpg|thumb|150px|Oak Bluff Colony sign (Hutterian Brethren)]] [[Hutterites]] are [[Hutterite German|German]]-speaking [[Anabaptists]] who live in communal agricultural colonies. They have 188 colonies in Alberta, 117 in Manitoba, 72 in Saskatchewan and 3 in British Columbia. These Canadian colonies began with 18 colonies founded in 1919.<ref>{{cite web | title = Regional index of Hutterite colonies | url =http://www.cedrontech.com/directory/ | date = | accessdate = 2014-06-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title =Mapping Hutterite Colony Diffusion in North America | url =http://www.mhs.mb.ca/docs/mb_history/53/hutteritediffusion.shtml | date = 26 June 2012 | accessdate = 2014-06-23}}</ref> [http://www.mhs.mb.ca/docs/mb_history/53/hutteritediffusion3.jpg Map]

There is no single [[Buddhist]] view concerning abortion, although it is generally regarded negatively."[http://www.bbc.co.uk/religion/religions/buddhism/buddhistethics/abortion.shtml Abortion: Buddhism]." ''BBC Religion & Ethics.'' Retrieved 15 January 2008. ==Scriptural views and the monastic code== Inducing or otherwise causing an abortion is regarded as a serious matter in the monastic rules followed by both [[Theravada]] and [[Vajrayana]] monks; monks can be expelled for assisting a woman in procuring an abortion.Harvey, Peter. Introduction to Buddhist Ethics (2000). Cambridge University Press. pg. 311-20 Traditional sources do not recognize a distinction between early- and late-term abortion, but in Sri Lanka and Thailand the "moral stigma" associated with an abortion grows with the development of the fetus. While traditional sources do not seem to be aware of the possibility of abortion as relevant to the health of the mother, modern Buddhist teachers from many traditions- and abortion laws in many Buddhist countries- recognize a threat to the life or physical health of the mother as an acceptable justification for abortion as a practical matter, though it may still be seen as a deed with negative moral or karmic consequences. ==Regional views== Views on abortion vary a great deal between different regions, reflecting the influence of the various Buddhist traditions, as well as the influence of other religious and philosophical traditions and contact with Western thought. ===Northern Buddhism=== Abortion is generally regarded very negatively among ethnic Tibetan Buddhists.Harvey, Peter. Introduction to Buddhist Ethics (2000). Cambridge University Press. pg. 328-29 Prior to the emergence of the Tibetan diaspora in the 1950s, Tibetans do not seem to have been familiar with abortion for reasons of medical necessity, and, facing little population pressure, saw little reason to engage in what they saw as the destruction of innocent life. Though no systematic information is available, abortion appears to be very rare among exiled Tibetans living in areas where abortion is legal. Tibetan Buddhists believe that a person who has had an abortion should be treated compassionately, and guided to atone for the negative act through appropriate good deeds and religious practices; these acts are aimed at improving the karmic outcome for both the mother and the aborted fetus, but authorities warn that they will not be effective if one has undertaken an abortion while planning to 'negate' it by atoning for it later. The [[14th Dalai Lama|Dalai Lama]] has said that abortion is "negative," but there are exceptions. He said, "I think abortion should be approved or disapproved according to each circumstance''."[[Claudia Dreifus|Dreifus, Claudia]]. (28 November 1993). "The Dalai Lama." The New York Times ===Southern Buddhism=== Laws and views on abortion vary greatly in Theravada Buddhist nations. Attitudes and laws in Thailand are generally more favourable towards abortion than in Sri Lanka.Harvey, Peter. Introduction to Buddhist Ethics (2000). Cambridge University Press. pg. 329-32 While abortion is still viewed as negative in Burma (Myanmar), it is allegedly also employed with some frequency to prevent out-of-wedlock births. Regarding attitudes towards abortion in Thailand, Peter Harvey notes:
...abortion is discussed not in the language of rights – to life or choice – but of ‘benefit and harm, with the intent of relieving as much human suffering in all its states, stages and situations as circumstances allow’, with an emphasis on reducing the circumstances leading women to feel that they need to have an abortion.
In November 2010, the issue of abortion and Buddhism in Thailand was thrust onto the front pages after 2000 fetuses were discovered stored at a temple in Bangkok. Abortion remains illegal in the country except in cases of rape or risk to the woman's health. Following the scandal, leading politicians and monks spoke out to reaffirm their opposition to abortion laws. Phramaha Vudhijaya Vajiramedhi was unequivocal: "In [the] Buddhist view, both having an abortion and performing an abortion amount to murder. Those involved in abortions will face distress in both this life and the next because their sins will follow them." Prime Minister Abhisit announced a crackdown on illegal abortion clinics and refused calls to change the law, saying that current laws were "good enough.""[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/nov/25/abortion-reform-buddhism-thailand Abortion reform is up against Buddhism in Thailand]." ''The Guardian Comment is Free.'' Published 25 November 2010. Peter Harvey relates attitudes towards abortion in Burma to [[Melford Spiro]]'s observation that Buddhists in Burma recognize a clear distinction between what may be regarded as 'ultimate good' in a religious sense and what is a 'worldly good' or utilitarian act. Despite the prevalence of illegal abortions in Burma due to economic difficulty, many Buddhists consider it against their religious beliefs.{{cite journal |last1=Ba-Thike |first1=Katherine |year=1997 |title=Abortion: A Public Health Problem in Myanmar |journal=Reproductive Health Matters |publisher=Reproductive Health Matters |volume=5 |issue=9 |pages=94–100 |jstor=3775140 |doi= 10.1016/s0968-8080(97)90010-0}} A 1995 survey on women in Burma showed that 99% thought abortion was against their religious beliefs. ===East Asia=== [[Buddhists in Japan]] are said to be more tolerant of abortion than those who live elsewhere.Barnhart, Michael G. (1995). [http://jbe.gold.ac.uk/5/barnh981.html Buddhism and the Morality of Abortion] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061212072421/http://jbe.gold.ac.uk/5/barnh981.html |date=12 December 2006 }}. ''Journal of Buddhist Ethics, 5.'' Retrieved 10 August 2006. In Japan, women sometimes participate in the Shinto-Buddhist ritual of [[mizuko kuyō]] (水子供養 — lit. 'fetus memorial service') after an induced abortion or an abortion as the result of a [[miscarriage]].Human Flower Project. [http://www.humanflowerproject.com/index.php/weblog/comments/mizuko_jizo/ ''Mizuko Jizo''], Retrieved on 29 April 2009. Similarly, in Taiwan women sometimes pray to appease ghosts of aborted fetuses and assuage feelings of guilt due to having an abortion; this type of ritual is called ''{{visible anchor|yingling gongyang}}''.{{Cite book | publisher = University of Hawaii Press | isbn = 978-0-82482428-0 | last = Moskowitz | first = Marc L. | title = The Haunting Fetus: Abortion, Sexuality, and the Spirit World in Taiwan |url=http://www.uhpress.hawaii.edu/p-2135-9780824824280.aspx | year = 2001 }} The modern practice emerged in the mid-1970s and grew significantly in popularity in the 1980s, particularly following the full legalization of abortion in 1985.{{Cite news | title = Appeasing the ghosts of the unborn | newspaper = Taipei Times | first = Bradley | last = Winterton | date = 2001-08-12 | accessdate = 2012-10-14 | url = http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/feat/archives/2001/08/12/0000098297/1 }} It draws both from traditional antecedents dating back to the Han dynasty, and the Japanese practice.Charles B. Jones, [http://www.h-net.org/reviews/showrev.php?id=6656 Review of Moskowitz, Marc L., ''The Haunting Fetus: Abortion, Sexuality, and the Spirit World in Taiwan.''] H-Buddhism, H-Net Reviews. August, 2002.{{cite journal | first = Fang-Long | last = Shih | date=September 2002 | title = Review of ''The Haunting Fetus: Abortion, Sexuality, and the Spirit World in Taiwan'' | journal = The China Quarterly | issue = 171 | pages = 765–767 | jstor = 4618793 }} These modern practices emerged in the context of demographic change associated with modernization – rising population, urbanization, and decreasing family size – together with changing attitudes towards sexuality, which occurred first in Japan, and then in Taiwan, hence the similar response and Taiwan's taking inspiration from Japan. == See also == * [[Buddhist ethics|Abortion]] * [[Religion and abortion]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Buddhism topics}} {{Abortion}} [[Category:Buddhism and society|Abortion]] [[Category:Religion and abortion]]

{{Italic title|reason=[[:Category:Japanese words and phrases]]}} [[File:Japanese Buddhist altar 001.jpg|thumb|An ornate ''butsudan'' with open doors displaying an enshrined [[Amida Buddha]]. A Butsudan in the [[Jodo Shinshu]] Buddhism tradition. ]] [[File:Close-up Butsudan at light on.jpg|thumb|Close-up view of the inner altar with the painted scroll of the Buddha]]
A '''''Butsudan''''', sometimes spelled {{nihongo||仏壇|'''Butudan'''|literally "[[Buddhism|Buddhist]] altar"}}, is a [[shrine]] commonly found in temples and homes in [[Buddhism in Japan|Japanese Buddhist]] cultures.<ref>Reader (1995:55) notes: "Over 60% of Japanese households have a ''butsudan'': many of the rest do not simply because no-one in the family has yet died and become an ancestor".</ref> A ''butsudan'' is either a defined, often ornate platform or simply a wooden [[Cabinet (furniture)|cabinet]] sometimes crafted with doors that enclose and protect a ''[[Gohonzon]]'' or religious icon, typically a statue or painting of a Buddha or [[Bodhisattva]], or a calligraphic [[mandala]] scroll.
If there are doors used, a Butsudan enshrines the ''Gohonzon'' icon during religious observances, and close after usage. In case of no doors, either a sheet of brocade or white cloth is sometimes placed over to render its sacred space. Traditional Japanese beliefs associate the Butsudan to be either a house of the [[Buddha]], [[Bodhisattva]] as well as deceased relatives enshrined within it. In some Buddhist sects, when a Butsudan is replaced or repaired by the family, a re-enshrinement ceremony follows.<ref>NHK World - Core Kyoto - The Butsudan Episode</ref>
A ''butsudan'' usually contains an array of subsidiary religious accessories, called ''butsugu'', such as candlesticks, incense burners, bells, and platforms for placing offerings such as fruit, tea or rice. Some Buddhist sects place ''[[ihai]]'' memorial tablets, ash of the deceased or ''kakochō'' death registers for deceased relatives either within or near the ''butsudan''.<ref>Cf. Reader (1995:55-56); Lewis (2007:178).</ref> The defined space which occupies the Butsudan is referred to as ''Butsuma''.
The butsudan is used for paying respects to family members who have passed away.
==Arrangement==
The arrangement and types of items in and around the ''butsudan'' can vary depending on the sect. A ''butsudan'' usually houses a ''[[honzon]]'', a statue or painting of the Buddha or a Buddhist deity that reflects the school which the family follows, though embroidered scrolls containing a [[mantra|mantric]] or [[sūtra|sutric]] text are also common. Other auxiliary items often found near the ''butsudan'' include tea, water and food (usually fruits or rice), an incense burner, candles, flowers, hanging lamps and evergreens.<ref>Cf. Buckley (2002:56-57).</ref> A ''[[standing bell|rin]]'' often accompanies the ''butsudan'', which can be rung during liturgy or recitation of prayers. Members of some Buddhist sects place ''[[ihai]]'' or tablets engraved with the names of deceased family members within or next to the ''butsudan''. Other Buddhist sects, such as [[Jōdo Shinshū]], usually do not have these, but may instead have pictures of the deceased placed near the ''butsudan''.<ref name=bregman>{{Cite book|title=Religion, Death, and Dying, Volume 3 |first=Lucy| last=Bregman|publisher=Praeger|year=2009|isbn=0897501217|ref=harv|page=164}}</ref> The ''butsudan'' is typically placed upon a larger cabinet in which are kept important family documents and certificates.<ref>Cf. Hamabata (1990:61).</ref>
==Social-spiritual relations== The ''butsudan'' is commonly seen as an essential part in the life of a traditional Japanese family as it is the centre of spiritual faith within the household, especially in dealing with the deaths of family members or reflecting on the lives of ancestors. This is especially true in many rural villages, where it is common for more than 90% of households to possess a ''butsudan'', to be contrasted with urban and suburban areas, where the rate of possession can drop down to below 60%.<ref>See Nakamaki (2003:24-25) for a discussion of the sociological stratification of ''butsudan'' ownership in modern Japan.</ref>
==See also== * [[Kamidana]] – analogous concept in [[Shinto]] * [[Gohonzon (Nichiren Buddhism)]] * [[Spirit house]]

'''David R. Carlin Jr.''' (born 1938) is a politician, professor of sociology and philosophy, and author.
==Life and career== Born in [[Pawtucket, Rhode Island]], he has resided in [[Newport, Rhode Island|Newport]] since 1972.
He was a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] majority leader of the [[Rhode Island Senate]].<ref>[http://www.projo.com/eastbay/content/projo_20040915_dist75.2a3a48.html The Providence Journal]</ref> His total period of service in the state Senate ran from 1981 to 1993. He made an unsuccessful bid for the [[Rhode Island's 1st congressional district]] in 1992.<ref>[http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/carfield-carll.html#SB00CLP1S Political Graveyard]</ref>
In 2012 he made a bid to return to the Rhode Island legislature, but was decisively defeated in a Democratic primary for the Rhode Island House of Representatives. He remains a registered Democrat, but is very much at odds with the ruling ideology of today's Democratic Party. For instance, he is strongly opposed to abortion and same-sex marriage.
In addition to his 12 years in the state Senate (1981 to 1993), he has served 12 years on the Newport School Committee. He was also at one time the chair of the Newport Democratic Party.
Carlin is the author of four books: ''The Decline and Fall of the Catholic Church in America'' (2003), ''Can a Catholic Be a Democrat?'' (2006), ''Homosexualism versus Catholicism'' (2012), and ''My Dear Bishops: an Open Letter to the American Catholic Bishops'' (2013). He has been an opinion columnist for two Catholic periodicals (Commonweal and Our Sunday Visitor) and two Catholic websites (Crisis and Aleteia).
Carlin has been a full-time professor at the Community College of Rhode Island since 1984. Currently he is a professor of [[sociology]] and [[philosophy]] at the Newport campus of [[Community College of Rhode Island|CCRI]].
